I do not know how much this claim is true, but [in the whitepaper which is the source of the tlaim that 80% is from renewable sources](https://coinshares.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/Mining-Whitepaper-Final.pdf), says: "in Sichuan where an estimated 80% of Chinese Bitcoin mining is located (48% of global), 90% of the total energy mix is renewable in  2017 ... @Klu9: Zeronet allows developers to create sites where an user can moderate what other users see. For example [Millchan](/17gCoQDCAAoQkzKRiajFNUAhnVD2gSNmuC/) board owner (not site admin) can mute bad user and hide his content from all the board readers (unless they disable the blacklist feature on the board). Another option is given to users thanks to [Blocklist feature](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1530020784_1AHEQxyRG9s6owyJHShB4U4rg9GL5FMX5K). Anyone can create blocklist and subscribers will no longer see unwanted users content.
Regarding bots creating shitloads of IDs, i think nofish who is the owner of zeroid.bit not disclosed his rate limitting policy regarding how many accounts can an IP create, but i am prety sure he mentioned there is such rate limit. But i doubt this is effective if there is some botnet with thousands of IPs, which will gain accounts slowly and then start damaging zeronet by SPAM. [This](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/1310) is related Github issue.
most of the users are on the clearnet. what are cheap clearnet web hosting systems without any single point of failure?

@leftside: trustful users disappear as time go, if these have right to add new trustful users, how would be prevented there is added bad user who will ruin experience to all people who enabled this trustful users mute-list feature?

**Other recommendations**

- Sign messages with DKIM. We don't authenticate messages signed with keys that use fewer than 1024 bits.
- Publish a SPF record.
- Publish a DMARC policy.

**IP guidelines**

- The sending IP must have a PTR record (i.e. a reverse DNS of the sending IP) and match the IP obtained via the forward DNS resolution of the hostname specified in the PTR record.
- The sending domain should pass either a SPF check or DKIM check.

(I think these requirements is a standard in mail servers requirements)

@ulrichard: "hibernation ... defeats full disk encryption". You think that Linux login (triggered when computer wake up) not protects the data enough, i would like to read more about this if it is true.

@ulrichard: i researched a bit, and [here](https://www.usenix.org/legacy/event/sec08/tech/full_papers/halderman/halderman_html/index.html) and [there](https://citp.princeton.edu/topics/memory/) is mentioned "Suspending a system safely - Our results show that simply locking the screen of a computer (i.e., keeping the system running but requiring entry of a password before the system will interact with the user) does not protect the contents of memory. Suspending a laptop's state (“sleeping”) is also ineffective, even if the machine enters screen-lock on awakening, since an adversary could simply awaken the laptop, power-cycle it, and then extract its memory state. Suspending-to-disk (“hibernating”) may also be ineffective unless an externally-held secret is required to resume normal operations.

**With most disk encryption systems, users can protect themselves by powering off the machine completely when it is not in use.**" so @ulrichard:, you were apparently correct. If one is afraid government or skilled thief will come and take/steal ones computer, one should be rather shutting down the computer when going away from it :-/ i have not researched if there are any new ways to hibernate/sleep without risk the decryption key will be obtained by the hacker.

regarding millchan and the nasty stuff. It is about not enabling the option to help download and distribute all site content and then not visiting bad boards and if you come to a bad images, there is option to either delete particular image, thumbnail or mute user/board which will hide and delete the content - you possibly already know that.

If you are talking about public ZN pr0xy, then there is no way to prevent bad content that people will browse on the site that is already downloaded. Proxies can be set to disallow users adding new sites.

@Ansho Rei: you are likely hosting low number of files comparing to other people who complain about memory usage. As Kaffie i am having same problem too. My Zeronet is using 4.5GB of memory (private bytes) and like 6GB of virtual memory. But i think @nofish has no time to replicate this or does not know how it can be fixed. Equally big problem for me is that zeronet is extremelly slow sometimes (for example loading image on Millchan or publishing content on Zerome takes not couple of second, but sometimes 30 seconds or many minutes). I maximized multithreading in [/Config](/Config) and verified the disk iops is low)
Only workarounds i think about is: A) distribute the hosted sites across multiple devices like Raspberry Pi's, VPSes... it will allow utilizing more CPU cores, more RAM. B) sell current computer and buy one with more RAM (using virtual machines to run multiple ZN instances may allow utilize more CPU threads - https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/2312
